title: 110_hr6388
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Government Accountability Office Improvement Act of 2008" and grants authority to obtain records. The "Government Accountability Office Improvement Act of 2008" grants the Comptroller General authority to obtain agency records for audit, evaluation, and investigative purposes, including through civil actions. The Act also allows for interviews with agency officers and employees. SEC. 3. ADMINISTERING OATHS.

Section 711 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow officers or employees to administer oaths to witnesses with prior approval from the Comptroller General.

SEC. 4. ACCESS TO CERTAIN INFORMATION. Sec. 721 of title 31, United States Code, grants the Comptroller General authority to access information without limitation from the Social Security Act or the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. This includes inspecting records and interviewing officers or employees regarding information disclosed under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The Comptroller General has the authority to obtain information, inspect records, and interview officers or employees under specific sections of the Social Security Act. Policies and procedures are in place to protect proprietary or trade secret information from public disclosure. The Comptroller General has the authority to obtain information, inspect records, and interview officers or employees under specific sections of the Social Security Act while ensuring the protection of proprietary or trade secret information from public disclosure. This section does not alter prohibitions against disclosure of sensitive information or affect existing protections against unauthorized disclosure. The Comptroller General has the authority to access certain information under SEC. 5 for reporting purposes. Section 719 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include an assessment of agencies' cooperation in providing personnel for interviews, answering questions, granting access to records, and other matters as deemed appropriate by the Comptroller General. The amendment to Section 719 of title 31, United States Code includes provisions for agencies to respond promptly to requests from the Comptroller General regarding specific matters. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on July 29, 2008.
